Introduction

Pharmacodynamics (PD) and pharmacokinetics (PK) are the foundations of pharmacology:



  • PK (what the body does to the drug) involves absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion (ADME), which influence properties such as bioavailability, volume of distribution, half-life, clearance, and steady-state concentration.  PK determines the drug concentration at the site of action.
  • PD (what the drug does to the body) involves drug-receptor behavior (agonism, antagonism), dose-response curves, therapeutic indices, and desensitization phenomena such as tolerance and tachyphylaxis.


This article covers the major aspects of PD.

Agonists



Drugs act on various receptor types, including G proteinâ€“coupled receptors (GPCRs) (

figure 1
), ion channels (
figure 2
), tyrosine kinases (
figure 3
), nuclear hormone receptors (
figure 4
), and enzymes.  These receptor signaling systems are discussed in more detail in a separate article.



Receptors exist in active and inactive conformations.  Agonists bind to the receptor active site, a highly specific pocket, stabilizing the active conformation and leading to downstream signaling.  Agonists are classified as:



  • Full (capable of eliciting a maximal response).
  • Partial (able to elicit only a submaximal response).

Full agonists



Full agonists produce a maximal response when occupying all available receptors.  Examples include:



  • Epinephrine (alpha-1, alpha-2, beta-1, and beta-2 adrenergic receptors).
  • Albuterol (beta-2 adrenergic receptors).
  • Morphine (mu opioid receptors).
  • Dexamethasone and other corticosteroids (nuclear glucocorticoid receptors).

Partial agonists



Partial agonists bind and activate receptors but produce a submaximal response, even at full receptor occupancy.  In the presence of stronger (full) agonists, partial agonists can function as antagonists because they compete for the same binding sites but produce a weaker maximal response.



Clinically, this dual behavior can be advantageous.  For example, buprenorphine is a partial opioid agonist used in medication-assisted treatment (MAT) for opioid use disorder (

figure 5
):  At low concentrations, it stimulates mu opioid receptors enough to replace the effect of recreational opioids, thereby preventing withdrawal and diminishing cravings.  However, it does not activate them fully, which prevents respiratory depression and limits euphoric effects.



Other examples include:



  • Aripiprazole (Dâ‚‚ dopamine receptor).
  • Buspirone (serotonin 5-HT1A receptor).

Antagonists



Antagonists block agonists (or endogenous ligands) from accessing the receptor active site.  They do so by binding at:



  • The receptor active site, either reversibly (competitive antagonism) or irreversibly (noncompetitive antagonism).
  • A distant (allosteric) site on the receptor (also noncompetitive antagonism), which changes the conformation of the active site.

Competitive



Competitive antagonists compete with agonists for the receptor active site.  They can be displaced by agonists present in high concentrations.  Therefore, competitive antagonists are reversible and surmountable.



Competitive antagonists are ideal for clinical situations in which rapid reversal is desirable (eg, heart block, opioid intoxication).  Examples include:



  • Naloxone (mu opioid receptor).
  • Atropine (muscarinic acetylcholine receptor binding site).
  • Flumazenil (benzodiazepine binding site on GABAA receptors).

Noncompetitive



Noncompetitive antagonists bind irreversibly to the receptor active site or to a different (allosteric) site that changes the receptor conformation to reduce its activity.  Their effects cannot be overcome by high concentrations of agonists because the receptors are permanently blocked until new receptors are synthesized.  Therefore, noncompetitive antagonists are irreversible and insurmountable.



Noncompetitive antagonists are ideal for clinical applications in which:



  • Prolonged block is desired, such as aspirin for irreversible cyclooxygenase-1 inhibition, lasting the lifespan of platelets (7-10 days).
  • Insurmountable block is desired, such as phenoxybenzamine for irreversible alpha-1 adrenergic receptor inhibition, to prevent hypertensive crises during massive catecholamine release (eg, pheochromocytoma surgery).

Mixed agonist-antagonists



Mixed agonist-antagonists act as full agonists on receptors in one tissue while acting as partial agonists or antagonists at different tissue sites.  Examples include:



  • Tamoxifen and raloxifene (selective estrogen receptor modulators [SERMs]) act as agonists in bone (eg, treatment of osteoporosis) but as antagonists in breast tissue (eg, chemoprevention of breast cancer).
  • Clomiphene (estrogen receptor) acts as an agonist in the ovaries (to promote ovulation) but as an antagonist in the hypothalamus (to prevent negative feedback from estrogen).


Several opioids (eg, pentazocine, nalbuphine, butorphanol) are also classified as agonist-antagonists because they have opposing effects on different opioid receptors (eg, mu agonist but kappa or delta antagonist).

Inverse agonist



As previously discussed, receptors exist in equilibrium between active and inactive conformations.  Many receptors, especially GPCRs, exhibit tonic (basal) activity even in the absence of an agonist or natural ligand.  For example, the beta-2 adrenergic receptor displays a low level of spontaneous activity even in the absence of catecholamines.  Like traditional agonists, inverse agonists bind to the receptor active site.  However, they preferentially stabilize the inactive conformation.  Therefore, inverse agonists can lower the tonic receptor activity below baseline levels.  In contrast, antagonists can block only further activation of receptors by agonists.

Dose-response curve

Michaelis-Menten analogy



The Michaelis-Menten model was originally developed to describe enzyme-substrate [E-S] interactions with the following idea:



[E] + [S] â†” [E-S] â†’ [E] + [P]



where P is a product of catalysis.  By analogy, this model also describes drug-receptor [D-R] interactions, where Drug [D] takes the place of Substrate [S] and Receptor [R] takes the place of Enzyme [E].  The model becomes:



[D] + [R] â†” [D] â†’ [R] + effect



The Michaelis-Menten graph describes the velocity of a reaction (y-axis) as a function of the substrate concentration (x-axis) using Vmax and Km.  In the drug-receptor analogy (

figure 6
):



  • Vmax becomes Emax, which indicates efficacy.  This determines the height of the dose-response curve.
  • Km becomes EC50, which indicates potency.  This determines the slope of the dose-response curve.


EC50 is the drug concentration that achieves 50% of Emax, just as Km is the substrate concentration that achieves 50% of Vmax.  A drug that is more potent has a lower EC50 (ie, less drug is needed to demonstrate effect).

Efficacy (Emax)



Efficacy (Emax) is the theoretical maximal effect of a drug (ie, with unlimited agonist dose).  It is represented by the ceiling of the dose-response curve.  Efficacy can be compared between drugs acting on the same receptor:



  • Emax (fentanyl) > Emax (codeine) (ie, any dose of fentanyl can produce greater analgesia than any dose of codeine).
  • Emax (atorvastatin) > Emax (pravastatin) (ie, any dose of atorvastatin can reduce LDL cholesterol more than any dose of pravastatin).


Noncompetitive antagonists are irreversible, preventing receptors from reaching their full effect regardless of how much agonist is present.  Therefore, noncompetitive antagonists lower the height of the dose-response curve, representing a lower Emax (

figure 7
).

Potency (EC50)



Potency (EC50) is the drug concentration at which the drug achieves half of its maximal effect (50% of Emax).  It is represented by the steepness of the dose-response curve.  Two drugs may be capable of producing the same maximal effect (equal efficacy) but require different doses to do so (different potencies).  The concept of potency is the basis for dose conversion tables, such as those used for loop diuretics (

figure 8
), opioids, and corticosteroids:



  • EC50 (bumetanide) > EC50 (furosemide) (ie, bumetanide 1 mg â‰ˆ furosemide 40 mg for the same oral diuretic response)
  • EC50 (hydromorphone) > EC50 (morphine) (ie, hydromorphone 1 mg â‰ˆ morphine 5 mg for the same oral analgesic response)


Competitive antagonists displace agonists from the receptor active site.  To achieve a given effect (eg, 50% of Emax), a higher concentration of the agonist is required.  Therefore, competitive antagonists shift the dose-response curve to the right, representing a higher EC50 (

figure 9
).

Therapeutic index



The therapeutic index (TI) compares the amount of a drug that causes a therapeutic effect to the amount that causes toxicity.  It is a population-level metric defined by the following ratio:



TI = TD50 / ED50



where TD50 (median toxic dose) is the dose at which the drug produces toxicity in 50% of the population and ED50 (median effective dose) is the dose at which the drug produces the desired effect in 50% of the population.  TD50 and ED50 are typically defined during dose escalation in preclinical studies in animals (LD50 is the dose at which the drug results in the death of 50% of animals).



  • Drugs with high TI have wide safety margins and include penicillins, vitamin B12 and folic acid, and proton pump inhibitors.  These drugs rarely cause overdose and do not require therapeutic monitoring.
  • Drugs with low TI have narrow safety margins and include warfarin, lithium, digoxin, and theophylline.  These drugs can easily cause toxicity and may require routine therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM).

Receptor sensitivity



Repeat or continuous drug exposure often leads to reduced responsiveness.  This phenomenon is classified as acquired tolerance or tachyphylaxis, depending on the time course and mechanism.

Acquired tolerance



Acquired tolerance is a gradual decrease in therapeutic effect when a drug is administered over days to weeks.  It can result from pharmacokinetic or pharmacodynamic mechanisms (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
).  Pharmacokinetic tolerance relates to altered drug metabolism after repeat exposure (eg, antiepileptic drugs induce CYP450 and accelerate their own clearance).  On the other hand, pharmacodynamic tolerance involves changes at the site of action:



  • Receptor downregulation:  Chronic albuterol use promotes beta-2 receptor internalization.
  • Blunted receptor responsiveness (reduced intracellular second messenger activity):  Chronic opioid use reduces G-protein signaling at mu opioid receptors.
  • Physiologic adaptation (activation of compensatory pathways to counteract the drug effect):  Calcium channel blocker antihypertensive therapy causes reflex activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system; chronic GABA agonist exposure (eg, alcohol, benzodiazepines) stimulates a compensatory increase in excitatory neurotransmitters (eg, glutamate).


Tolerance can be overcome by increasing the drug dose, providing a long drug holiday (eg, until receptors regenerate), and, sometimes, by rotating drugs within the same class (eg, opioids).

Tachyphylaxis



Tachyphylaxis is a form of acute tolerance with a rapid loss of response, often by the second or third dose.  It is generally caused by the immediate depletion of preformed mediators or cofactors necessary for the drug effect.  For example:



  • Sympathomimetic nasal decongestants (eg, oxymetazoline) quickly deplete mucosal norepinephrine, leading to rebound congestion.
  • Nitrovasodilators (eg, nitroglycerin, nitroprusside) produce reactive oxygen species that react with and deplete thiol groups necessary for nitric oxide production.


Tachyphylaxis can be managed with intermittent drug withdrawal (eg, nitroglycerin patch on for 8 hours, off for 16 hours).

Spare receptors



Spare receptors are extra receptors not needed for maximal response.  In other words, maximal response (Emax) can be reached even when only a fraction of receptors are occupied.  Spare receptors have important clinical implications that deviate from the standard Michaelis-Menten kinetics:  In tissues with large reserves of spare receptors, an antagonist (even if irreversible/noncompetitive) may not block enough receptors to prevent a maximal response.  In other words, an agonist can still produce a maximal response even in the presence of the irreversible/noncompetitive antagonist.  As a result, the antagonist appears ineffective until its concentration is high enough to block all spare receptors.

Summary



Pharmacodynamics describes how drugs affect the body through interactions with receptors that can elicit activation (agonism), inhibition (antagonism), or suppression of baseline activity (inverse agonism).  Full agonists fully activate receptors, whereas partial agonists produce submaximal responses and can function as antagonists in the presence of full agonists.  Antagonists block receptor activity without activating them and can be competitive (reversible and surmountable) or noncompetitive (irreversible and insurmountable).  Drug-receptor interactions follow principles similar to those of enzyme kinetics, where efficacy (Emax) reflects the ceiling of the dose-response curve (representing maximal achievable effect) and potency (EC50) reflects the slope of the dose-response curve (representing the dose needed for 50% efficacy).  Competitive antagonists reduce potency, whereas noncompetitive antagonists reduce efficacy.  The therapeutic index reflects drug safety margins, with narrower therapeutic indices requiring close monitoring due to toxicity risks.  Repeat drug exposure can lead to tolerance (gradual reduction in effect) or tachyphylaxis (rapid loss of effect), which may require dose escalation or drug holidays.
